content.question: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations. A commercial laundry company that cleans uniforms for a large mail delivery business plans to investigate the effectiveness of two different laundry detergents (G and T) in cleaning dirty uniforms for the drivers of the delivery business. The uniforms are composed of two garments: a shirt and a pair of shorts, both of which are the same fabric and color and receive the same amount of wear when worn by the delivery drivers. A random sample of <math alttext="40" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>40</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> dirty uniforms was selected from those sent by the delivery business and Detergent G was randomly assigned to clean the shirt for <math alttext="20" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> uniforms and the pair of shorts for the other <math alttext="20" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> uniforms. Detergent T was assigned to clean the other garment for each uniform. After the uniforms were cleaned, an employee at the company who was not aware of which detergent was used rated the cleanliness of each garment on a scale from <math alttext="0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="100" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, with larger values indicating greater cleanliness. The difference in cleanliness ratings for each uniform, measured by the difference in the rating for the garment that received Detergent G and the rating for the garment that received Detergent T, was recorded. The histogram shows the distribution of the differences in cleanliness ratings (G minus T) for the <math alttext="40" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>40</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> uniforms. (a) Describe the distribution of the differences in cleanliness ratings for the <math alttext="40" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>40</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> uniforms.

frqParts.text: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations. A commercial laundry company that cleans uniforms for a large mail delivery business plans to investigate the effectiveness of two different laundry detergents (G and T) in cleaning dirty uniforms for the drivers of the delivery business. The uniforms are composed of two garments: a shirt and a pair of shorts, both of which are the same fabric and color and receive the same amount of wear when worn by the delivery drivers. A random sample of <math alttext="40" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>40</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> dirty uniforms was selected from those sent by the delivery business and Detergent G was randomly assigned to clean the shirt for <math alttext="20" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> uniforms and the pair of shorts for the other <math alttext="20" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> uniforms. Detergent T was assigned to clean the other garment for each uniform. After the uniforms were cleaned, an employee at the company who was not aware of which detergent was used rated the cleanliness of each garment on a scale from <math alttext="0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="100" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, with larger values indicating greater cleanliness. The difference in cleanliness ratings for each uniform, measured by the difference in the rating for the garment that received Detergent G and the rating for the garment that received Detergent T, was recorded. The histogram shows the distribution of the differences in cleanliness ratings (G minus T) for the <math alttext="40" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>40</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> uniforms. (a) Describe the distribution of the differences in cleanliness ratings for the <math alttext="40" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>40</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> uniforms.

The laundry company will use a hypothesis test, at <math alttext="alpha equals 0.10" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to determine whether the sample data provide convincing statistical evidence that the mean difference in cleanliness ratings between Detergent G and Detergent T is different from zero. Let <math alttext="mu sub difference" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>f</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> represent the mean difference in cleanliness ratings (G minus T) for all uniforms sent by the delivery business that could be cleaned with the two detergents. The hypotheses are: <math alttext="H sub 0, colon, mu sub difference equals 0. H sub a, colon, mu sub difference is not equal to 0." overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub><mo>:</mo><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>f</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mspace linebreak="newline"></mspace><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>a</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>:</mo><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>f</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub><mo>≠</mo><mn>0</mn><mspace linebreak="newline"></mspace></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> (b) Identify a feature of the distribution of the sample differences in cleanliness ratings that might raise concerns about whether the sampling distribution of <math alttext="x bar sub difference" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>f</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is approximately normal, and explain why it is reasonable to conclude that the sampling distribution of <math alttext="x bar sub difference" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>f</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is approximately normal in this case.

Assuming all conditions for inference were met, the hypothesis test was conducted and resulted in a test statistic of <math alttext="t is approximately equal to negative 0.932" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>≈</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.932</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.(c) Based on the results of the hypothesis test, what conclusion can be made about the two laundry detergents? Justify your answer.

An employee of the laundry company believes that cleanliness rating is related to uniform use (the number of times a uniform has been worn). The scatterplots show, by detergent, the relationship between uniform use and cleanliness rating for the <math alttext="40" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>40</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> uniforms. (d) Describe and compare the association between uniform use and cleanliness rating for the two laundry detergents.

(e) Suppose a uniform is randomly selected from those in the study. For which laundry detergent (G or T) is there a greater probability of selecting a uniform that has a cleanliness rating of at least <math alttext="60" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>60</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> given a uniform use of less than <math alttext="100" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>? Interpret what this means in the context of the study.

(f) Provide a recommendation to the laundry company that describes how uniforms should be assigned to Detergent G or Detergent T based on uniform use if the goal is to assign the detergent with the greater cleanliness rating. Justify your answer based on the two scatterplots.

topic.text: 1.6: Describing the Distribution of a Quantitative Variable

skill.text: Skill 2.A: Describe data presented numerically or graphically.
